title: Why does Pyke get a lethal indicator?
body:
Most ultimates in this game sevrve the purpose of finishing off enemies.

If Pyke's R could ONLY be used on targets who were at critical health, then maybe the indicator is fair, since it lacks all other utility.

Why does he get an indicator? I don't really get it.

replies.body: What's so wrong with it though? Only the Pyke player sees it and It doesn't make the champ stronger. It just eliminates most of the guesswork involved. I personally am OK with any champ with an Ult execute to have some kind of indicator.

He's squishy as fuck and feels super reliant on picks. He feels a lot like blitz minus the tank factor. I'm fine with him having an indicator as he's normally bursted and dead before he even gets his ult away.

I gotta disagree here.

Pyke's ultimate goal as an assassin is to secure kills.
Thats literally his job, so if youre playing pyke, thats the 1 thing the player should have to actively _try_ to do.

I feel like if your **one** job is to kill someone, you should at least have to work for it, and not get a big neon flashing sign that tells you when and where to push your buttons.
Dude, no way. Pyke is slippery and durable as fuck, IMO.

I'm definitely with you on this one.

Tbh I dont think any champ should have an indicator.
Like... its not hard, if you play a champ a lot you'll have a very good idea of how much damage you do.
No need to spoon feed people. Especially people who already have a powerful execute move.

If I'm Veigar I have to guess wether my ult will kill someone, and my whole point of existing is to provide damage.
Why does someone like Garen, who is a tank, get free spoon-feeding?

You mean Pyke, right?

Garen doesn't get an indicator.

Yea, Garen, if you're the villain the sword above your head lights up when Garen can execute you.

Ikr....
Oh, really?! Holy, that's just garbage.

You're telling me...

How many training wheels does that champ need?? O_o
